title: Thursday, 24th March, 2016

11:01 am

PM

http://www.rns-pdf...97T_-2016-3-23.pdf

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 446.60, down 31 (-6.49%), High: 470.00, Low: 442.60, Volume: 5.67m
PM

Indeed

11:07 am
BE

"Commodity kaboom!", says Credit Suisse

BE

Honestly, it does.

PM

As well they might

11:07 am
BE

BE

We have downgraded our
major bank estimates by 1-2% in FY16E reflecting higher bad debts arising
from a handful of distressed institutional credits. Our view at this juncture is
that these problems represent isolated rather than systemic issues (more
like the 2001-2002 "Fallen Angels" cycle than the 2008-2009 GFC cycle),
and so our outer year estimates are materially unchanged. Whilst not
regarding the announcements by ANZ and WBC as heralding a full blown
credit cycle we are of course watchful, and note that the major banks have
all "bled" their collective provision coverage aggressively coming out of the
GFC, leaving the sector vulnerable to a medium-term provision re-stocking
earnings shock.

BE

This is specific to the Oz banks, but the readacross is pretty clear.

11:08 am
BE

We have downgraded our estimates broadly
through higher bad debt charges following announcements by ANZ and
WBC in relation to bad debt pressures arising from low commodity prices
(affecting mining and related industries), evolving work-outs of sizable
single-name institutional banking credits, rising consumer banking
impairments (personal loans – especially in Western Australia, some
deterioration in auto finance, and the exhaustion of positive write-backs
(business & commercial banking).

PM

Direct readacross to Stan, that's for sure

PM

Given the rolling crisis across European investment banks (including CS itsel)

11:09 am
PM

And all the net interest margin stuff

PM

Something of a perfect storm quietly raging here

PM

Or not so quietly, actually

11:10 am
BE

Should also note that Morgan Stanley's selling StanChart, largely on valuation.

BE

As in, it's too highly valued for a bank that won't grow revenue anywhere close to where management's targeted.

BE

Standard Chartered stock has rallied c.25% from the lows in
February. We see revenue as the next challenge and without deeper
cost cutting we struggle to see how the 8% 2018 ROE guidance can
be met (MSe 4.5%) – stay UW with c.15% downside

11:10 am
BE

Dovish Fed and commodity price recovery should support asset quality
to a degree, but concerns likely to stay elevated. Lower US$ financing
costs (MS economists only expect one Fed rate hike in '16) and a commodity
price recovery from lows should provide some relief for borrowers. We also
note activity such as Rosneft potentially taking a stake in Essar Oil showing
deals could mitigate some risk on the $8bn liquidation book. We expect focus
to move to emerging risks on the 'good book', which still has an elevated cost
of risk (1.16% annualised in 2H15); we reduce loan loss estimates and give
credit for normalisation to 50bps cost of risk by '19e, which lifts our PT.

BE

Revenue recovery the next challenge. With 1Q16 revenue run-rate likely
no better than slightly up vs 4Q15 and the rest of year facing headwinds from
de-risking, lower for longer rates and weak external demand in Asia (e.g.
export volume growth for China, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan contracted by
8.0% y/y in Jan-Feb 2016; see note), we now model $13.1bn of revenue in
2016e (7% below consensus). We also note increasing pressure in HK
mortgages (c.12% of group loans) as lenders compete for low risk assets –
front book spreads are down 10-15bps in the last few months. Our
interpretation of guidance suggests that a heroic 15% core revenue CAGR
2016-18e is now required to hit the 8% 2018 ROE target

BE

Too early for deeper cost cuts? In a softer than expected revenue
environment the obvious lever to reach for is cost control. While SCB already
have an ambitious cost program in place with $2.3bn of gross savings (vs
$10bn ex-levy 2015 cost base), we note that Credit Suisse, who announced
their new business plan and rights issue at around the same time as SCB, have
already added another CHF0.8bn (c.25%) to their cost savings target due to
weak-than-expected market conditions. Our base case is for no extra cost
cutting at SCB near term but this could be an upside risk.
Stay Underweight - c.20% downside to Price Target. While valuation at
0.6x 2016e TNAV factors in much caution and the stock could rally further if
sentiment improves on the Asian macro outlook, however when we look at the
earnings power, even as far out as 2019 we find it hard to get excited

11:14 am
BE

Partly because competitors have matched its USP

BE

(I think its USP, from an operational perspective, was the ability to deliver school uniforms and court appearance suits by 8am the next morning.)

BE

But there's also the bigger question about whether a cleanup of the credit book has had an effect on the business that wasn't necessarily visible when that cleanup first came into force.

11:16 am
BE

And if Directory goes into reverse, so does Next's growth.

BE

BE

11:18 am
BE

(When I talk quick I end up talking like an analyst. Apologies for that.)

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Reasonably good numbers
Unsurprising set of FY results from Next with sales in line at £4,150m and underlying PBT at £821.3m marginally better than consensus. FY EPS came in at £4.43, c2% better than consensus. FY numbers are reasonably good and the balance sheet remains strong with Next expecting to reduce net debt in FY17 by £110m to £740m and return surplus cash of £350m.
Very cautious outlook
Nonetheless, what will likely disappoint investors today is the very cautious guidance into FY17 due to a slowing UK economy, increased uncertainty and volatile clothing sales. While management acknowledges upside risk if the weather is more normal in FY17, they prefer to reduce growth guidance into FY17 by 2pps. Next Brand sales now are expected to grow by -1% to +4% from +1-5% with the PBT guidance in a range of £784-858m. The new FY17 PBT midpoint is £821m which assumes no growth y/y and compares to consensus at £852m.

11:18 am
BE

Unsurprisingly the shares reacted very badly to the downgraded guidance today. There is merit for management to guide cautiously ahead of the UK referendum on EU membership on 23rd June but we were a bit surprised by the aggressive management of expectations without the company itself doing badly fundamentally. Clothing sales are actually doing better YTD according to Barclaycard data than they did in the two last months of 2015. We believe that management today chose to be disproportionately cautious to cover all negative scenarios and leave any positive surprises as an option. Nonetheless at least until June we expect shares to be at best volatile but long-term investors may find an interesting entry point. Next trades on 14.5x CY16E PE.

BE

And Jefferies.

BE

Revising FY17E guidance down again - part macro/part mea culpa. Whilst Next
has reported FY16 PBT of £821m, broadly in-line, management has lowered FY17E guidance
for the second time in 3 months. This is in part due to uncertainty surrounding Brexit and
slowing real disposable income growth. It is also in part due to Next's mea culpa on not
keeping pace with some omni-channel development and other issues. Areas Next is now
focussing on include, inter alia,: improving the mobile offer, targeted e-mails and direct
marketing, personalising the website offer, allowing customers to pick up from third party
parcel shops, growing credit customers and faster buying.
FY17E PBT now expected to be flat, +- 4.5%. Sales growth guidance is now -1%
to +4% (was +1-6%) and for the first time, Next has admitted its very high 20% operating
margin could fall, with PBT guidance of £784m-£858m, the mid point of which is 3.6%
below current consensus.
Early buy back in January means fewer share buy backs special divs in FY17e.
Year end net debt has risen to £850m as having already paid four special dividends the
company took an opportunity in January to bring forward £151m of share buy backs. This
means that share buy backs/special divs are expected to contribute only c.3% in FY17e,
meaning total shareholder return is expected to be between 1% and 10%.
Trading on c.14x cal 17 EPS, little to attract. On Next's revised guidance and with the
stock down c.8% to 6125p (vs -1-2% for the FTSE100) we estimate the company is trading
on c. 14x cal 17 EPS. That's still not attractive to us.

11:19 am
BE

And Exane, whose excellent retail team is just off the call.

BE

At a bearish meeting, Next management emphasised the extent the headwinds the business is facing. Weaker consumer demand partly explains it, but there appear to be a number of company specific issues. These largely concern the directory business, where management flagged the toughening competitive environment alongside the decline in credit customers as major drivers. Early initiatives to abate the declines look to have not proven successful, so instead attention has turned to improving the website, improving delivery and improving availability. These are sensible improvements, but are in-line with what most retailers would do, and by management own admission may be sufficient to offset the headwinds over the next 12 months (and no more than that), but the outer year outlook also looks challenged. With negative LFL’s expected to persist in retail which also faces tough margin comparatives, the outlook for Next is more clouded than it has been for a while, and the potential fall from grace as a best-in-class retailer potentially transforms into a structurally challenged one has potential to weigh on both forecasts sentiment and valuation. Today’s share price reaction is a sharp reflection of that, but in the absence of profit growth, it is difficult to see what catalyst will drive investors to return.

PM

Next weakening further as you type

11:20 am
PM

Off 12.7% live

BE

Here's Exane's bullet points on Directory, which I suspect is the real story in all this.

BE

- Credit customer declines represent a major headwind
- Lowering APR has not helped it abate, but may help from a regulatory perspective
- Moving away from offering tiered credit, don't believe it will add value. Instead directing resource to taking furniture interest-free credit in house. May then look to roll out interest free as a driver of credit adoption.
- No sign of lower propensity spend since average balances have grown, but management wouldn't rule it out
- Credit customers: -4%, spend +1% (once spend per customer)
- Cash customers: +35%, spend +31%
- Aim to improve delivery, availability, mobile offer, personalisation and better management of the catalogue
- On delivery the lead vs competition has been eroded. Next are looking to embrace click and collect points (5,000 parcel shops) and bring in 2hr delivery windows
- On availability, demand used to be driven by the catalogue, as was buying etc therefore. No longer appropriate given customer shopping patterns. Hence availability fell from 75% to 65% yoy over Autumn/Winter. Have initially thrown stock at the problem, will look to re-write systems to manage more effectively. 1-2% sales opportunity.
- On the catalogue, this remains an importance driver but can be more selective in distribution). £8m saving will be reinvested into online mktg where next have found alternative routes to customer recruitment.
- All of this work is considered to be sufficient to "more or less" offset the underlying problem of credit customers and growing competition
- Amazon is considered more of a threat than an opportunity, and next do not expect to partner with them in the UK

11:21 am
BE

Also note, the tone of the call wasn't about being cautious for caution's sake -- which is often the way Next goes. It felt rather more like a straight up warning, apparently.

PM

Interesting

BE

So, yeah, it's the weather. But it's also the possibility that Next's heading into a strategic cul de sac where growth disappears.

PM

This Rockefeller gone green stuff flagged on the right.

PM

Quite a moment really

11:23 am
PM

Selling out of Exxon and all other fossil stuff

PM

Actualy will throw up the statement

PM

The Rockefeller Family Fund is proud to announce its intent to divest from fossil fuels. The process will be completed as quickly as possible, as we work around the complications of modern finance, which is increasingly dominated by alternative investments and hedge funds.

While the global community works to eliminate the use of fossil fuels, it makes little sense—financially or ethically—to continue holding investments in these companies. There is no sane rationale for companies to continue to explore for new sources of hydrocarbons. The science and intent enunciated by the Paris agreement cannot be more clear: far from finding additional sources of fossil fuels, we must keep most of the already discovered reserves in the ground if there is any hope for human and natural ecosystems to survive and thrive in the decades ahead.

We would be remiss if we failed to focus on what we believe to be the morally reprehensible conduct on the part of ExxonMobil. Evidence appears to suggest that the company worked since the 1980s to confuse the public about climate change’s march, while simultaneously spending millions to fortify its own infrastructure against climate change’s destructive consequences and track new exploration opportunities as the Arctic’s ice receded. Appropriate authorities will determine if the company violated any laws, but as a matter of good governance, we cannot be associated with a company exhibiting such apparent contempt for the public interest.

11:24 am
PM

To operationalize this decision, the Board has instructed its advisors, effective immediately, to eliminate holdings of ExxonMobil, and all coal, and tar sands-based companies outside the portions of the portfolio managed by third parties, and to keep exposures for these three categories of investment below 1 percent across the entire portfolio. The Family Fund’s Finance Committee will soon be entering the second phase of its divestment work, which will entail seeking suitable alternatives to certain commingled funds now held. The field of Socially Responsible Investing is dynamic and growing and we are confident that a variety of options will soon emerge for mid-sized endowments such as ours.

Needless to say, the Rockefeller family has had a long and profitable history investing in the oil industry, including ExxonMobil. These are not decisions, therefore, that have been taken lightly or without much consideration of their import. But history moves on, as it must. Indeed, it is past time for all people of good will to do everything in their collective power to make our new path one that recognizes the deep interdependence between humanity’s future and the health of our natural systems.

PM

BE

11:39 am
BE

Here's UBS.

BE

With H1 PBT having been only £26m, there always appears risks to the FY. However,
the level of drop through on weaker sales is still highly negative in our opinion, with a
sales guidance cut of just over £20m at the midpoint, equating to a mid-point cut of
£20m on the PBT guidance. After a recent rally we expect a double digit negative share
price reaction.

BE

And Investec.

11:39 am
BE

FY16 is a year when Renishaw’s revenues are declining (due to the non-repeat of some exceptional orders from FY15) and costs are rising, as the group invests heavily in new capacity and new products. This mismatch has been evident for the last year and we consider that the group’s record still underpins faith in management’s medium- to long-term judgement. Nevertheless, the shares are likely to respond to the warning. Our estimates, TP and recommendation are under review.

Lower guidance. Renishaw has cut its guidance, as a result of revenues for the year to June 2016 now looking lower than its previous expectations. This does not come as a complete surprise. New guidance is for revenue of £420-440m (previous guidance £440-465m, our estimate £442m, consensus £442m), PBT of £67-85m (previous guidance £85-105m, our estimate £84.9m on their basis, consensus £89.1m). Thus the mid-point of PBT guidance has moved down by £19m or 20% from £95m to £76m, on a £22.5m or 5% cut in revenue. Even with Renishaw’s high gross (and contribution) margins, this high rate of drop-through suggests that costs are now going up more quickly than anticipated. Also, remember that the last change in guidance was a cut in revenues but not profit, so perhaps the two warnings should be taken together.
Reaction. Clearly, consensus estimates are likely to react to this warning, although it should be noted that most analysts had pitched their numbers at the conservative end of the previous range and we were at the bottom of the guidance range (in January we said that “Guidance requires a stunning H2”).
Message. Qualitatively, this tells us nothing new about Renishaw, which is investing heavily for anticipated future growth. We shall consider the implications of the announcement, but for now our estimates, target price and recommendation are under review.

undefined
BE

Mitie, also warning. Though only on sales.

Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 240.69, down 23.71 (-8.97%), High: 251.30, Low: 239.50, Volume: 1.94m

PM

11:43 am
BE

BE

Stifel, for example

BE

Full year profits to be in range of market estimates, but revenue to be below. We are not expecting any below
the line one-off costs, and this should be a signal of good cost management. This said, underlying work to
improve cost efficiency must have progressed during H2.
Mitie’s trading update provides a lacklustre message broadly in line with our
update note from Monday “More caution to growth rates”. The message on
revenue is more downbeat, but profit should be about where we have
indicated.
H2 as expected has not seen the recovery in revenue expected. FM ended the
year with a flow of new wins. Property Management has been softer in H2,
after a strong H1 as the market has prepared for the statutory 1% reduction in
social housing rents from 1 April. Healthcare is described as making progress:
we take that to mean management is still anticipating a return to profit in H2
FY17.

11:44 am
BE

The message into the future is for modest growth next year as we noted. Mitie
will have to work hard to maintain margins with cost pressure coming in over
the next years from a range of legislative change. We expect increasing
adoption of technology solutions to be a key tool in managing these additional
burdens. At least on the National Living Wage, Mitie is confident, having
worked through discussions with clients, that it will be able to pass most of the
impact through.
The key is the group’s ability to convert profit to cash. This will only show once
we have a look at the full year numbers. As ever, attention will also be on the
movement of provisions and mobilisation costs. Despite the slowed growth, if
margins can be held, the healthcare business stops being a drag and
conversion of profit to cash becomes consistent, the share price – free cash
flow yield of a rising 6% – signals undervaluation. The reality of the here and
now will however likely dominate for now with yields poised to rise today.

BE

And Canaccord.

BE

With the absence of any exceptional costs in FY16 the full year result should present a
cleaner year. Whilst recent contract wins and the stability of margins are positives, there
is, in our view, a more cautious tone for 'modest' growth through FY17E, reflecting both
the more uncertain macro environment (and potential implications of Brexit) but also the
more specific contracting environment within outsourcing. Whilst the space continues
to present attractive opportunities, organic growth has been under some pressure in
the latest reporting season and contracts continue to require a greater working capital
commitment. As a result management is more cautious in its optimism for the future,
recognising the challenges posed by regulatory enforced increases in staff costs and
the resultant desire for customers to drive greater technology-led efficiencies. Across
individual contracts, this increased use of technology is expected to translate into a
reduced revenue outlook but stable profitability.

11:45 am
BE

Changes to estimates
We move our estimates for FY16E in line with the statement, resulting in an EPS
reduction of 3% and also move our expectations for FY17E (which were toward the top of
the range) down by 8% to reflect the likelihood of lower organic growth.
Valuation
As shown overleaf, a +12m PE of 10x has provided the lower bound over the past
five years and on our revised forecasts the shares will currently trade on 10.6x. On a
multiples basis Mitie remains at a discount to sector peers having been hindered by
several years of weak earnings momentum. A more cautious tone through FY17 may
allow for a period of more steady delivery against expectations and the opportunity for
the shares to re-rate. We maintain our BUY recommendation with the shares on a FCF
yield of c7% and Div Yield of 4.6%, but move our TP down to 300p, based on a FY17 PE
of 12x, in line with historic averages.

BE

Incidentally, on the outsourcers, there was a really good bit of work from Stifel earlier in the week that we tried to summarise here:

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz43eg90GFT

11:51 am
PM

I've only glanced, but it looks worth your time

PM

Estimates of the number of binary options and forex companies in Israel vary from 20 to several hundred. The IVC Research Center, a company that provides information about Israel’s technology sector, estimated in its 2015 yearbook that there are 100 online trading companies in Israel, the overwhelming majority of which fall into the categories of forex and binary options. IVC estimates these companies employ more that 2,800 people in Israel. However, the yearbook states, “it’s difficult to gauge the actual size of the online financial trading industry in Israel,” in part because the industry is “low-key” and its “Israel nexus is often understated.”

PM

What’s worse, though, and blatantly corrupt, The Times of Israel was told, is that, at some companies, the house is bent. A variety of ruses are used. The potential payout for a correct prediction is complex, opaque and calculated to minimize the company’s loss. If an asset is behaving in a predictable way — say, the price of copper starts to climb following an earthquake in Chile — the company will pull that asset from the online platform. At some binary options firms, the online platform is manipulated to provide false results that ensure the customer loses.

Here's what Numis makes of it all.

BE

The union of Vectura and Skyepharma is one of the most complementary mergers
in the UK healthcare sector. It will create a £1bn+ FTSE250 UK respiratory champion
with strong, globally competitive technologies and capabilities across the entire
spectrum of dry powder, smart nebuliser and now metered dose inhalers, making
it the partner of choice in targeting the airways and allowing it to address 60%
more of the $35bn global respiratory market than Vectura did on its own. We see
the merger as a strategically and financially logical step-up for Vectura, with the
combined company offering critical mass and attractive growth at a good price. We
re-introduce our Buy recommendation with a 12-month target of 264p.

prospects (VR315 and wholly owned FAVOLIR / SCIPE assets).

BE

● The ongoing roll-out of Flutiform is set to transform the P&L with revenues and
underlying EBITDA set to approximately double and then grow at 14% and 20% CAGR
respectively to end FY2021. EPS CAGR is higher, at 33%.
● We see EPS accretion of 24% in year 1 (FY2017, 7% ROI), growing to c.60% over
years 2-3 (FY2018-2019, double digit ROI), then falling to single digits as VR315
royalties come through and are spread over a higher share count.
● The deal washes its face on our risk-adjusted SOTP analysis (£470m vs £460m
consideration and estimated costs).
● Our risk adjusted SOTP value is 14% diluted from our previous 271p target. The
potential for platform synergies are not captured in this approach, which to date has
attributed no terminal value to the assets.
● Skyepharma will bring in significant near-term cash-flows to give management a
multitude of options to make the leap to self-commercialisation and build lasting
sustainable enterprise value. The time feels right to switch to a multiple-based
valuation.

BE

● We see the increased size, liquidity and FTSE250 listing increasing awareness of
Vectura's steep forecast trajectory. A rating relative to BTG feels appropriate. Applying
a P/E in line with BTG of 24.7x (vs 29% risked EPS CAGR) our risked FY2020 EPS of
16.8p (fully taxed) and discounting back, we see a multiples based valuation of 294p.
We blend this with our SOTP of 234p to derive our target price of 264p, reflecting the
need to complete the transition to self commercialisation.
● On our initial projected consolidated EPS forecasts, Vectura's P/E drops to single digits
by year 3 (FY2019), now driven mostly by Flutiform: a strong buy signal in our view.

BE

And from yesterday, RBC.

BE

Strategic rationale: Strategically, we see the deal enhancing Vectura’s capabilities (oral, pMDI and commercial manufacturing) but think the financial rationale is the main motive for the combination. Vectura has a larger pipeline but its partnered assets have only recently launched and its financial profile still less developed than SKP’s, which has a smaller pipeline but with key assets launched and delivering profit growth (FY15A EBITDA margin of 37.5%). Combined, we see the two offering a healthy pipeline of opportunities with a strong financial profile.

Turbo charged financials: We choose not to update our forecasts (or valuation) until completion of the deal and instead provide a view on the combination below and within the note. The New Co will have an implied Mcap of £1.1bn and offer a revenue, EBITDA and EPS 3-year CAGR (FY17E-20E) of 31.7%, 41.3% and 32.1% respectively with a FCF yield of c10%. More importantly, the Group will become attactive on conventional multiple metrics, PE of 12.6x FY18E EPS (March YE) given the earnings ramp delivered by SKP.

Valuation mixed: We think Vectura have paid a fair but full price for SKP which, when executed alongside recent share price weakness has magnified the potential dilution. That said, we acknowledge that acquisition targets that fit well rarely coincide with perfect market conditions. Our conventional valuation for Vectura (SoTP; DCF and rNPV) suggests fair value of New Co at c190p (down from 206p) once the deal completes. However, we think investors should focus on the New Co financial profile which shows the shares trading on an implied EV/EBITDA of sub 10x by FY18E and 12.6x FY18E EPS. Considering upcoming newsflow (VR315 in particular) alongside growth and cash generation metrics we believe a re-rating likely from these low levels given the growth on offer.

BE

Valuation:

Given the risk associated with assets not yet approved by regulators or still in their launch phase we utilise a SoTP model; for partnered launched assets we utilise NPV analysis with a WACC rate of 7% (Vectura is net cash) and no terminal value beyond Vectura’s patent protection. For partnered pipeline assets we use risk-adjusted NPVs with a discount rate of 10%, standard industry associated risk adjustments and no terminal value beyond Vectura’s patent protection on the products. For wholly owned pipeline assets we also use a rNPV (again a discount rate of 10% and standard risk adjustments) but apply a terminal with a growth rate of -2.5%. This provides our price target of 205p and our Outperform rating, although near term newsflow on VR315 in the US and on both Utibron & Seebri assets (also US) may drive our valuation towards 230p. We have not updated our forecasts or valuation for the SKP merger, but provide sensitivity analysis to our forecasts and valuation within.

Price target impediments:

We see two key impediments to our price target and rating:

1. VR315 – The launch of VR315 in the US is arguably the most important launch from Vectura’s pipeline over the coming months. A generic of Advair (aka Seretide) we anticipate the product being directly substitutable and, with only one competitor (Mylan) in the short term we have modelled only partial price erosion. If this launch is delayed then this would erode an estimated c7p for each 6 month delay and we see downside risk as capped at c.50p to our valuation if the product fails to launch altogether.
2. Utibron & Seebri – Whilst we believe Novartis is unlikely to shelve these assets in the US, it could find a commercial partner given the cost of launching and as the market becomes more competitive. We see downside risk of c.20p to our valuation if the assets are not launched in the US.
